title: ESPN's 'O.J.: Made in America' wins Oscar for best documentary feature | Other Sports | Sporting News
text:
SPORT February 26, 2017 9:40pm EST February 26, 2017 9:40pm EST The "30 for 30" story of O.J. Simpson's life makes history for ESPN. From left: Los Angeles Police Det. Mark Fuhrman and Judge Lance Ito; O.J. Simpson; prosecutor Marcia Clark (AP Photo) 
Updated at 9:40 p.m. ET 
Updated at 9:40 p.m. ET 
ESPN's "30 for 30" film series celebrated a milestone Sunday night when the network's production "O.J.: Made in America" won an Academy Award for best documentary feature. 
The five-part, 7 1/2-hour series on the life of football Hall of Famer O.J. Simpson is the first ESPN production to be nominated for and win an Oscar. It collected a series of other awards leading up to Sunday. 
MORE: Sports movies that won Academy Awards 
The series' director, Ezra Edelman, spoke during his acceptance speech of Simpson's ex-wife Nicole Brown Simpson and her acquaintance Ronald Goldman, who were brutally slain in 1994 in Los Angeles. Simpson was accused of killing the two but was acquitted in 1995 during a murder trial that continues to fascinate Americans. 
"This is for them and their families," Edelman said. 
A jury in a civil trial later found Simpson liable for the killings. 
Edelman said the movie was also for "victims of police violence, of police brutality, racially motivated violence and criminal injustice." Watch This
